data.value: Acquired 51% of Longo’s, a specialty grocery retailer with 36 stores in Ontario, and its Grocery Gateway e-commerce business.
The Longo’s footprint will be expanded by two stores in fiscal 2023.
Empire will have invested $1.5 billion over five years to renovate close to half of our store network.
RSCs are officially renamed the Bill, David and Donald Sobey RSCs to honour the Sobey family’s incredible legacy.

elements.title: Business Acquisitions and Foreign Currency Translation

data.value: Business acquisitions are accounted for by applying the acquisition method, recognizing identifiable assets and liabilities at fair value.
Goodwill arises on acquisition and represents the excess of acquisition cost over fair value of identifiable net assets.
Assets and liabilities of foreign operations are translated at exchange rates in effect at each reporting period end.
Cash and cash equivalents include cash and guaranteed investments with maturity less than 90 days.
Warehouse inventories are valued at lower of cost and net realizable value, on a weighted average cost basis.

elements.title: Goodwill and Impairment of Non-Financial Assets

data.value: Represents the excess of the purchase price of the business acquired over the fair value of the underlying net tangible and intangible assets.
Annually for goodwill and indefinite life intangibles.
Higher of FVLCD (Fair Value Less Costs to Dispose) and VIU (Value in Use).
Recognized immediately in net earnings or loss; cannot be reversed for goodwill.
Reviewed each reporting period for impairment based on cash flow independence.
Reduced to recoverable amount; recognized in selling and administrative expenses.
If not related to goodwill, carrying amount can be increased to revised estimate.

Goodwill Allocation from Business Acquisitions and Impairment Testing

data.value: Goodwill arising from business acquisitions is allocated at the lowest level within the organization where it is monitored. It is allocated to operating segments within the Food retailing segment, including Sobeys National, Farm Boy, Longo's, Quebec, Atlantic, Ontario, Lawtons, and West (with a summarized Total).
The annual test of goodwill was performed in the third quarter of fiscal 2022 with no impairment recorded. Goodwill is not amortized but tested for impairment annually or more frequently if needed.

For operating segments other than Farm Boy, the recoverable amount is determined based on FVLCD using industry earnings multiples ranging from 7.0 to 14.0. Farm Boy’s goodwill was measured using a VIU model based on discounted cash flow projections with a discount rate of 9.6%, projected cash flow growth between 2.0% and 6.0% over 10 years, and a terminal growth rate of 2.0%.
Components include statutory tax expense, non-deductible and non-taxable items, tax rate changes and differentials, investment tax credits, tax estimate revaluation, and other adjustments.
Notable changes include a substantial increase in current tax expense and significant swings in deferred tax components such as tax rate changes.
Longo’s – a long-standing, family-built network of specialty grocery stores in the Greater Toronto Area and its Grocery Gateway e-commerce business
3,187,348 Non-Voting Class A shares at $129.6, cash of $196.6, and a contingent note payable of $10.7

Assets and liabilities as at May 10, 2021: Assumed cash: 0.6, Receivables: 10.8, Inventories: 47.3, Prepaid expenses: 71.0, Income taxes receivable: 0.4, Property and equipment: 719.0, Right-of-use assets: 262.4, Intangibles: 261.3, Goodwill: 451.6; Liabilities include Accounts payable and accrued liabilities: -73.4, Lease liabilities: -262.4, Long-term debt: -34.3, Other assets and liabilities: -23.7, Deferred tax liabilities: -59.0, Non-controlling interest: -323.7; Total consideration: 3369.0
For the year ended May 7, 2022, contributed sales of $1,041.1 and net earnings (net of non-controlling interest) of $9.9

Goodwill of $451.6 arises from excess acquisition cost over the fair value of net identifiable assets, attributable mainly to the acquired workforce and expected customer base. Intangibles of $261.3 relate to the brand name, loyalty program and software. The transaction includes complex NCI arrangements with put and call options and recognition of a financial liability of $239.7 under IFRS 9.

elements.title: Operating Lease Payments to be Received

data.value: Sales for the quarter ended May 7, 2022 increased by 13.3% primarily due to the additional week of operations, the acquisition of Longo’s, higher fuel sales, increased food inflation and benefits from Project Horizon initiatives.
Gross profit for the quarter ended May 7, 2022 increased by 11.6% primarily as a result of higher sales due to the additional week of operations.
Operating income increased, reflecting improved efficiencies and revenue growth.
EBITDA showed strong growth due to higher sales.
Net earnings improved slightly, owing to overall revenue growth despite cost pressures.
Earnings per share saw a modest increase, indicating shareholder profitability.
Diluted earnings per share also increased.
The company increased its dividend per share from $0.13 to $0.15.
$1,363.7 million (2022) compared to $1,299.5 million (2021), change of $64.2 million
$1,277.0 million (2022), increase due to higher sales and gross profit
$86.7 million (2022), significant growth due to Crombie REIT and Genstar
$745.8 million (2022), increase of $44.3 million from $701.5 million (2021)

elements.title: Eligible Dividends and Non-GAAP Financial Measures Disclosure

data.value: ‘Eligible dividends’ receive favorable tax treatment. Dividends are designated as eligible at the time of payment per CRA administrative position and the language on the Company website.

The MD&A includes non‐GAAP measures (e.g., gross profit, EBITDA) used to assess liquidity, debt servicing, and funding for capital expenditures. Gross profit is calculated as sales less cost of sales, and EBITDA is derived from net earnings before finance costs, income tax, depreciation, and amortization.
Shows a positive trend with net earnings and EBITDA increasing, and notable rises in depreciation and amortization costs alongside growth in operating income.

elements.title: Financial Performance Metrics (in millions of dollars)

data.value: This table presents a consistent growth trend across key financial performance metrics over fiscal years 2020 to 2022, with significant improvements in EBITDA, net earnings, and operating income.

elements.title: Financial Metrics and Shareholders' Equity Metrics

data.value: Sales from stores in the same location in both reporting periods; used to assess sales trends by removing effects of store openings/closures.
Calculated as gross profit divided by sales; an important profitability indicator.
EBITDA divided by sales; used to evaluate performance and cost structure.
Net earnings attributable to owners of the parent divided by average shareholders’ equity; a supplementary measure of profitability.

data.key: Funded debt to total capital ratio
data.value: Funded debt divided by total capital; a rising ratio indicates increased reliance on debt in the capital structure.
Funded debt divided by trailing four-quarter EBITDA; used to assess financial condition.
Trailing four-quarter EBITDA divided by trailing four-quarter interest expense; a higher ratio indicates stronger interest coverage.
Calculated from shareholders’ equity net of non-controlling interest divided by total common shares outstanding. The accompanying table shows growth from $14.51 in 2020 to $18.82 in 2022.
Increased from 3,924.6M in 2020 to 4,991.5M in 2022 as indicated by the table.
Slight decrease from 270.4M in 2020 to 265.2M in 2022.

elements.title: Management’s Statement of Responsibility for Financial Reporting

data.value: The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with IFRS or GAAP and reflect management’s best estimates and judgments.
Management has established and maintains a system of internal control ensuring the integrity of the financial statements, safeguarding of assets, and prevention/detection of fraudulent reporting.

The Board of Directors, through its Audit Committee composed solely of independent directors, oversees financial reporting. The committee regularly meets with financial management and external auditors, and reports its findings to the Board.
Michael Medline, President and Chief Executive Officer; Matt Reindel, Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer

elements.title: Independent Auditor’s Report – Empire Company Limited

data.value: The accompanying consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Empire Company Limited and its subsidiaries as at May 7, 2022 and May 1, 2021, and its financial performance and cash flows for the respective periods, in accordance with IFRS.
Consolidated balance sheets, statements of earnings, comprehensive income, changes in shareholders’ equity, cash flows, and accompanying notes.
53 weeks ended May 7, 2022 and 52 weeks ended May 1, 2021
Conducted in accordance with Canadian generally accepted auditing standards
The auditors are independent as per the relevant ethical requirements.

elements.title: Key Audit Matter - Valuation of Retail Inventories

data.value: Inventories are valued at the lower of cost and estimated net realizable value using weighted average cost or the retail method
The retail method uses the anticipated selling price less normal profit margins and reduces cost by allowances received from vendors

Tested operating effectiveness of controls related to inventory valuation and physical count process; performed independent test counts; traced underlying data to purchase invoices and retail selling prices; evaluated profit margins and tested adjustments for vendor allowances, internal charges, and shrinkage estimations

Considered a key audit matter due to the magnitude of the inventories balance, numerous store locations, volume of transactions between count dates, and significant management estimations and judgments
Includes commentary on management’s responsibilities and the auditor's considerations regarding other information in the annual report

This is a balance sheet comparing financial positions between May 7, 2022 and May 1, 2021. Total assets increased from $15,173.9M to $16,593.6M. Total liabilities increased from $10,675.9M to $11,459.7M. Notable changes include growth in retained earnings from $2,363.1M to $2,914.2M. The company maintained a strong asset base with significant property, equipment, and right-of-use assets. Current assets and liabilities show healthy liquidity with cash and cash equivalents of $812.3M as of May 7, 2022.
Non-controlling interest (Note 24): 142.4, See accompanying notes to the consolidated financial statements. Signed by James M. Dickson and Michael Medline (Directors)

Calculated using the asset and liability method on temporary differences.
Recognized only to the extent probable to be utilized against future taxable income.
Valued at the lower of carrying value and fair value less costs to sell.
Recognized initially at cost and accounted for using the equity method.
Conducted at each reporting period to determine potential write-downs.

elements.title: STANDARDS, AMENDMENTS AND INTERPRETATIONS & Financial Disclosures

data.value: Mandate recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for transactions with deductible and taxable temporary differences at initial recognition; effective for reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2023, with early adoption permitted; the Company is assessing the potential impact.

Narrow-scope amendments to IFRS 3, IAS 16, IAS 37 and Annual Improvements to IFRS Standards 2018-2020 to clarify guidance, wording, and correct minor issues; effective for annual periods beginning on or after January 1, 2022; no material impact expected on the financial statements.

data.key: IASB January 2020 Amendment on Liability Classification
data.value: Amendment clarifying the classification of liabilities as current or non-current based on rights existing at the end of the reporting period, aligning definitions and emphasizing that only established rights affect classification; effective for periods beginning on or after January 1, 2023, with early adoption permitted; the Company is assessing the impact.
For the year ended May 7, 2022, inventory expense was $22,502.7 and a write-down of $2.1 was recorded for inventories held below cost to net realizable value.

Lease receivables increased from $540.1 to $553.1, loans receivable from retail associates and notes receivable details are provided; total long-term receivables increased slightly from $544.2 to $549.1, with specific decreases in notes receivable and amounts due within one year.

Assets related to land, buildings, and equipment previously used in retail operations; in 2022, three properties were sold with proceeds of $23.7 and a pre-tax gain of $4.3, compared to two properties sold in 2021 with proceeds of $36.8 and a pre-tax gain of $30.7.
Revenues slightly decreased from $117.3M to $116.6M; expenses increased from $72.2M to $76.4M, resulting in a decline in net earnings of approximately 10.9% year-over-year.
Current assets decreased while current liabilities slightly increased, leading to a reduction in net assets and carrying amount of investment between 2021 and 2022.
Significant growth observed with revenues increasing by 679% and net earnings maintaining a consistent profit margin of around 53% year-over-year.
Current assets doubled while liabilities decreased, yet net assets experienced a significant decline from 2021 to 2022.
Deferred lease assets are the largest component, followed by investments. Derivative assets are minimal, with other assets contributing to a total of 22.3.

data.value: The table compares key components of comprehensive income for the two reporting dates, highlighting a notably higher contribution from actuarial gains in 2022.
Current: Legal: 6.6, Environmental: 1.4, Restructuring: 24.7, Total: 32.7; Non-current: Legal: 0, Environmental: 39.6, Restructuring: 4.6, Total: 44.2

Legal costs relate to outstanding claims arising in the ordinary course of business. Environmental provisions reflect estimated remediation costs for fuel stations and other sites discounted at a pre-tax rate of 6.0%. Restructuring provisions, including store closures and conversions, were made and reversed (discounted at a pre-tax rate of 7.0%) and recorded under selling and administrative expenses.

The Company participates in various multi-employer pension plans. Approximately 12% of employees (and franchisees/affiliates) participate. Defined benefit plans are accounted for as defined contribution plans due to inadequate information. For the year ended May 7, 2022, an expense of $38.4M (2021 - $40.0M) was recognized as contributions in selling and administrative expense. Contributions are expected to continue in fiscal 2023.

Defined benefit plans data: For Pension Plans, balance decreased from $750.2M (beginning) to $612.3M (end) largely due to a significant remeasurement loss (-$107.8M) and benefits paid (-$53.6M). For Other Benefit Plans, the obligation declined from $107.5M to $88.8M.

Pension plan fair value decreased from $603.7M (beginning of year) to $522.9M (end of year) with a remeasurement loss of $63.5M and benefits paid of $53.6M. Other benefit plans show minimal activity with employer contributions and benefits paid roughly offset.

data.value: Pension plans: Total fair value of plan assets at $5229M with accrued benefit liabilities of $(89.4)M, and unfunded and partially funded obligations reported. Other Benefit Plans have no assets, with accrued benefit liabilities of $(88.8)M (improved from $(107.5)M in 2021).

elements.title: Financial Costs Analysis, Free Cash Flow, and Capital Structure Reconciliation

data.value: The table reconciles finance costs to interest expense over three periods, showing an increase in net finance costs from $66.7M in 2021 to $82.0M in 2022 and an upward trend in final interest expense from $65.8M to $82.2M, after adjustments for finance income, pension costs, and accretion expenses.

A three‐year comparison (2020-2022) of finance costs and related adjustments. It details finance income, pension finance costs, and accretion expenses, with total interest expense slightly rising to $279.7M in 2022.

Free cash flow is defined as cash flows from operating activities plus proceeds from disposals, less acquisitions and payments (including interest paid and lease liabilities), used by management to assess funds available for debt repayment, dividend payments, and other investing/financing activities. It is reconciled to GAAP measures.

The reconciliation table presents funded debt and total capital (calculated as funded debt plus shareholders' equity, net of non-controlling interest) as at three different balance sheet dates. Notable figures include an increase in funded debt from $6.94B to $7.46B and total capital rising from $10.87B to $12.45B, with long-term lease liabilities being the largest debt component.

data.value: The 'Number of Shares' table details the authorized, issued, and outstanding shares: 2002 Preferred shares (991,980,000 on both dates), Non-Voting Class A shares (754,605,023 on May 7, 2022 vs 760,984,006 on May 1, 2021), and Class B common shares (122,400,000 on both dates).

data.key: Share Capital and Outstanding Shares Summary
data.value: This table summarizes share capital movements including a decrease in Non-Voting Class A shares, repurchase of common shares, issuance of shares for business acquisition and stock-based compensation, and a steady level of Class B shares. The total capital stock increased from $1,969.8M to $2,026.1M between May 2021 and May 2022.

A separate table shows the activity in shares held in trust. It details the beginning balance, shares purchased, shares issued, and the ending balance, with a notable reduction in the number of shares and associated capital.
The company paid common dividends of $156.8 in 2022 compared to $139.4 in 2021, representing $0.60 per share versus $0.52 per share, indicating an increase in dividend payment.

An offer clause states that if an offer is made to purchase Class B common shares, holders of Non-Voting Class A shares are entitled to receive a follow-up offer at the highest price per share paid under such an offer.

Another table, titled 'Financial Comparison 2022 vs 2021', presents other income data such as a significant net gain on lease terminations in 2022, changes in net gain on disposal of assets, and lease income, contributing to an overall improvement in total other income from $53.0 to $86.8.

elements.title: Supply Chain Disruptions Including Impacts of Climate Change

data.value: Over reliance on key vendors, consolidation of facilities, severe weather conditions, natural disasters, climate change driven disruptions, geopolitical disruptions.
Contamination of properties and facilities, underground storage tanks at retail fuel locations.
Unexpected events or natural hazards causing operation cessation.
Inability to attract, retain talent and manage performance.
Limited ability to control franchisees and affiliates' business operations.
Renegotiation of collective agreements and risk of labour disruption.

Management continues to closely monitor economic conditions, including foreign exchange rates, interest rates, inflation, employment rates and capital markets. Uncertainty in the economic environment could adversely impact demand for the Company’s products and services.

Sobeys is a significant purchaser of food product which is at risk of cost inflation due to rising commodity prices. Should rising costs materialize in excess of expectations, there could be a negative impact on sales and margin performance.
The Company’s long-term debt objective is to maintain the majority of its debt at fixed interest rates. Any increase in interest rates could increase interest expense and adversely affect cash flow.
The Company is a significant consumer of electricity, other utilities and fuel. Unanticipated cost increases could negatively affect the Company’s financial performance.

The Company operates pharmacies subject to laws governing the sale of prescription drugs. Changes in reimbursement models or failure to comply with these regulations could impact financial performance.

elements.title: Risk Factors Impacting Company's Reputation and Financial Performance

data.value: Any failure to adhere to the Company’s policies, law, or ethical business practices could significantly affect its reputation and brands, thereby negatively impacting financial performance. The Company has a Code of Business Conduct and Ethics and an anonymous, confidential whistle blowing hotline, though effectiveness cannot be guaranteed.

Social reform movements via protests and media campaigns bring public awareness to issues such as diversity, animal welfare, ethical sourcing, nutritional labeling, and human rights, all of which can affect the Company’s reputation and financial performance. Oversight is provided by the Executive Committee and the Board of Directors.

The Company has programs and progressive employment policies to promote a healthy and safe workplace across its stores, distribution centres, and offices. These policies are reviewed by the Human Resources Committee. Non-compliance could adversely impact reputation or financial performance.

The Company’s capital allocation process focuses on securing attractive real estate locations for retail, commercial, and residential operations. Success in this area depends on negotiating favorable leases and purchasing high-potential sites; challenges in these negotiations could impact operations.

The Company uses a third-party loyalty program and recently announced a new co-owned loyalty program to be rolled out in fiscal 2023. Decisions made by third parties or partners and failure to manage program changes effectively may adversely impact reputation and financial performance.

Risks associated with trade relationships, particularly changes in trade agreements and tariffs between Canada, the United States, and other countries, can lead to increased costs and product unavailability, negatively affecting customer experience.

The Company’s dependency on access to sufficient capital and financial resources to fund growth and investments poses a risk. Failure to maintain adequate financial resources could hinder growth or ability to meet financial obligations.

Changes in federal and provincial laws, rules, and regulations can materially impact financial results. Compliance costs and potential legal proceedings due to non-compliance could materially affect the Company’s performance.
Changes in income tax regulations and accounting pronouncements could negatively affect the Company. Mitigation involves monitoring new activities, improving technology, and internal controls.
Credit ratings are subject to change without assurance, potentially affecting the Company's cost of accessing the capital markets and overall financial health.
Decisions regarding capital allocation are reviewed by the Board to ensure appropriate returns; failures in this area could harm growth and financial performance.
The Company primarily operates in CAD, but faces foreign exchange risk with USD, Euro, and GBP fluctuations, which could adversely impact financial results.
Obligations under registered defined benefit pension plans may require contributions differing from estimates, which can adversely affect the Company's financial performance.
High levels of debt may limit the Company's flexibility and ability to secure additional financing, impacting dividend declarations, capital expenditures, and strategic opportunities.
The Company is partially self-insured for operational risks and also purchases coverage from third-party insurers, though these measures may not fully mitigate exposure.

elements.title: Key Audit Matters – Recognition of Vendor Allowances

data.value: Key audit matters are those items which, in the auditors’ professional judgment, were of most significance in the audit of the consolidated financial statements for the 53 weeks ended May 7, 2022.
Recognition of vendor allowances, including volume-related allowances, purchase discounts, listing fees, and other allowances, recognized as a reduction of cost of sales and related inventories.
Complexity in determining performance obligations due to the number and variety of vendor agreements requiring significant management judgment.

Testing of operating effectiveness of controls related to vendor allowances, evaluation of management’s determination, confirmation of vendor allowance receivables, and tracing amounts to cash receipts/net settlements.
Refer to note 2 (f) – Basis of preparation (Vendor allowances) and note 3 (x) – Summary of significant accounting policies (Vendor allowances)

elements.title: Audit Procedures and Going Concern Disclosure

data.value: Management is responsible for assessing the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern and uses the going concern basis of accounting unless liquidation or cessation of operations is intended.

The auditor’s objective is to obtain reasonable assurance that the consolidated financial statements are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an appropriate auditor’s report.
The audit includes identifying and assessing risks of material misstatement, with an emphasis on higher risks from fraud that may involve collusion, forgery, or intentional misrepresentations.
Auditors obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit to design appropriate audit procedures, not to express an opinion on the effectiveness of internal controls.
Matters of most significance communicated with those charged with governance are highlighted, except when disclosure is restricted by law or other overriding considerations.
The audit is conducted in accordance with Canadian generally accepted auditing standards.

Sobeys provides financial support under franchise and operating agreements to offset retail store losses, reduce rental payments, and assist with other operating expenses. The agreements vary in provisions.

During fiscal 2009, Sobeys entered into a standby letter of credit arrangement for certain franchisees and affiliates related to equipment purchase and installation. Under this contract, Sobeys must provide a letter of credit equal to the outstanding guarantee, renewed annually, with a requirement to fund the greater of $6.0 or 10% of the authorized obligation.

As at May 7, 2022, the guarantee amount under the credit enhancement contract was $6.0. Additionally, letters of credit were issued in an aggregate amount of $82.4 (2021 - $99.3) to support other obligations, and guarantees related to commercial development agreements total $40.0.

Sobeys faced a reassessment from the Canada Revenue Agency for fiscal years 1999 and 2000 regarding GST on tobacco sales to eligible Indigenous Peoples totaling $13.6. Although Sobeys disputes the requirement to collect GST, funds equal to this amount have been deposited with CRA and recorded as an other long-term receivable pending resolution.

Various claims and litigation arising from ordinary business operations are disclosed; management does not consider the exposure material but acknowledges inherent uncertainty, and ongoing tax audits could raise issues in the future.

elements.title: Liquidity Risk and Fair Value Analysis

data.value: Liquidity risk is the risk that the Company may not have cash available to satisfy financial liabilities as they come due. The Company maintains a committed credit facility and monitors capital markets and cash flows to optimize its cash position and assess funding requirements.

A table shows the contractual maturities of significant financial liabilities as of May 7, 2022, with total liabilities of $5,054.7 million. The largest amounts are due in 2023 ($3,632.2 million), dominated by accounts payable and accrued liabilities ($2,988.9 million), followed by long-term debt ($1,629.7 million).

A comparison table indicates that the long-term debt carrying amount decreased from $1,225.3 million on May 1, 2021 to $1,176.7 million on May 7, 2022, while the total fair value fell from $1,406.7 million to $1,210.3 million.

As of May 7, 2022, financial assets and liabilities were classified into IFRS 13 levels. For financial liabilities, Level 1 is nil, Level 2 is $4.2 million, and Level 3 is $342.1 million. For financial assets at FVTPL, Level 1 is nil, Level 2 is $0.9 million, and Level 3 is nil.

elements.title: Management of Disclosure Controls and Procedures

data.value: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer
Crombie REIT and key management personnel

Assumptions are used when management assesses impairment of non-financial assets such as investments in associates and joint ventures, goodwill, intangible assets, property and equipment, right-of-use assets and investment property. Management estimates the recoverable amount of each asset or CGU based on the higher of value-in-use (“VIU”) and fair value less costs of disposal (“FVLCD”). The VIU calculations are based on expected future cash flows.
Estimates and judgment are used in the measurement of lease liabilities and right-of-use assets. Key assumptions include determination of discount rates and lease term expectations.

Assumptions are applied when management assesses the timing and reversal of temporary differences and estimates the Company’s future earnings to determine the recognition of current and deferred income taxes.
Estimates and assumptions are used to calculate provisions when the Company estimates the expected future cash flows relating to the obligation and applies an appropriate discount rate.
The Company has supply agreements with varying terms for purchase of goods for resale, some of which include volume related allowances, purchase discounts, listing fees, and other discounts.
Accounting for the costs of defined benefit pension plans and other post-employment benefits requires the use of several assumptions.
For business acquisitions, the Company applies judgment on the recognition and measurement of assets acquired and liabilities assumed.

data.key: Non-controlling interest put and call options
data.value: The Company applies estimates and judgment to the non-controlling interest put and call options the Company enters into as part of business acquisitions.

elements.title: Liability for Defined Benefit Plans and Revenue Recognition

data.value: The liability recognized on the consolidated balance sheets for defined benefit plans is the present value of the defined benefit obligation at the reporting date less the fair market value of plan assets.
Current market values are used to value benefit plan assets.
Remeasurements, comprising actuarial gains and losses and the return on plan assets are recognized immediately on consolidated balance sheets.
Service cost on the net defined benefit liability is included in selling and administrative expenses.
Termination benefits are recognized as an expense at the earlier of when the Company recognizes related restructuring costs.
Revenue is recognized upon delivery and acceptance of the goods, measured at the expected consideration net of discounts.
The Company recognizes vendor allowances as a reduction of cost of sales and related inventories.
Finance income and expenses are reported on an accrual basis.
Basic EPS is calculated by dividing earnings available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding.
The Company operates both equity and cash settled stock-based compensation plans for certain employees.
The company is dedicated to strong environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices.
Empire announced commitments to reduce carbon footprint through a comprehensive Climate Action Plan.
Set science-based targets (SBTs) aligned with greenhouse gas reduction targets from the Paris Agreement.
The company has been supporting communities and families, contributing to various initiatives.
